div.head: General
div.p: Dāxla is an oasis in the Egyptian Western desert. To the north lies the oasis of Farāfra, to the east lies Khārga. It has been inhabited since the Pleistocene and some significant excavations have taken place there. Nowadays, the region is mostly agricultural.

div.head: Research history
div.p: The oases dialect group is most closely related to the Middle Egyptian dialects, with some elements of Western (Maghreb) dialects, as shown by Woidich 1993.

Within the group of oases dialects, according to Woidich, Farāfra and Dāxla form a sub-group. Owing to isolation, this sub-group is very heterogeneous and the Dāxla region itself is divided into four groups: Central, East, West and North-West. Behnstedt and Woidich 1982 is a paper on the oases dialects, including short texts from Mūšiyya (West) and Bīr Umm iṣ-Ṣiġīr (Central), and Dāxla is also included in their atlas called Die ägyptisch-arabischen Dialekte (Behnstedt and Woidich 1985).

On Bašandi, which belongs to the Eastern group, see Woidich 2000 and 2001, as well as 2004. See Woidich 2003 and 2005 on baby-talk in Bašandi. Woidich 1998 is a text from Balāṭ, also in the Eastern region. On al-Qaṣr (North-West), see Woidich 2002 (in German). On Ismint (Central), see Woidich 2006. Material on the Western group is largely unpublished, save for some texts with annotations in Behnstedt and Woidich 1988.
Woidich 2007 explores practices of ethno-medicine in the Dāxla oasis. Woidich 1995-97 deals with the syntax of negation.

div.head: Dictionaries
div.p: Lexical data from Dakhla is included in the glossaries (Arabic-German and German-Arabic) published by P. Behnstedt and M. Woidich (Behnstedt & Woidich 1994; Behnstedt & Woidich 1999).
